Manage Events

A generated event represents information about an action or state related to a device. Sometimes an event can pertain to the PW EMS itself. Most generated events contain configuration, connectivity, and state change information. Events can also provide information about alarm conditions, warnings, or errors that occur on devices.

  1. In the navigation bar, click Events. You can choose how to display events and take certain actions with events by using the event configuration bar selections, which are shown below and discussed in more detail in the following steps.
  2. In the Events window, the ACTIVE EVENTS tab displays by default. The following event fields are described for the list of active events that are automatically generated or updated:
    NOTE: You can control how default or optional columns appear in the ACTIVE EVENTS table by clicking the column display icon . In the drop-down list, check or uncheck the checkbox for any the columns described below that you want to filter in the table. Unchecking a checkbox hides a column and checking a checkbox makes a column appear in the table. Events are refreshed every 10 seconds.

    Field

    Description
    Download icon

    Click this icon to download events. In the pop-up menu that displays, select either Excel for an Event.xlsx file or CSV for an Event.csv file. The file type that you select downloads to your web browser's default download location on your system.
    Object ID Displays the logging module name or internal path. Refer to Configure the System Logging Profile topic for more information.
    Severity

    Displays the severity of the event. The following severity levels can be displayed for an event:

    (Default column) Displays the severity of the event. Click the Severity drop-down list and check the check box next to each of the following event severity levels to filter event columns you want to appear in the table:

    • Critical - The alert indicates that action must be taken immediately. If no actions are taken, there may be physical, permanent, and irreparable damage to your system.
    • Major - Critical conditions exist. The functionality has been seriously compromised and a loss of functionality, hanging applications, and dropped packets may occur. If no actions are taken, your system suffers no physical harm, but ceases to function.
    • Minor - Error conditions exist. The functionality has been impaired to a certain degree and you might experience compromised functionality. There is no physical harm to your system, but you need to take actions to keep your system operating properly.
    • Warning - Warning conditions exist. Some irregularities in performance. These conditions are noteworthy and you should take actions to keep your system operating properly.
    • Clear - Any cleared messages.
    • Info - Informational messages are appearing.

    Any event of a checked event severity level appears in the table. Uncheck the checkbox of an event severity level to hide any events that belong to this event type so they do not appear in the table.
    Message Displays the system message ID and type of error.
    Network Trigger Element Displays the name of the Network Element that triggered the event.
    Time Stamp Displays the day, month, year, and Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) time for when the event was triggered.
  3. Click an event once to provide a detailed event view. For example, an Info event is expanded to show detailed information for it:
    The fields described in the following table appear only in the detailed event view:

    Field

    Description
    Alarm Name The alarm associated with this event. For example: CWS_REBOOT_REQ
    Object ID The module or internal path for the object involved.
    Description Description of the event action. For example: CWS received a reboot request.
    Raised by Indicates the entity that raised the event.
    Device ID This is a combination of the Organization Unique ID (OUI) for Parallel Wireless (41733), product class (C19999) and product serial number (for example, S3837C2X1113972) that were made.

    For example the complete Device ID displays like this: 41733-C19999-S3837C2X1113972

    Functional Area Displays what type of service or network element is involved.
    Device Name Displays the device name that triggered the event. This name may display the same as the Device ID, if it was not re-named by a user.
    Alarm ID Unique alarm identifier (ID) generated and assigned by the PW EMS.
    Acknowledge Indicates whether the event has been acknowledged or not. Click the Acknowledge drop-down list and check the checkbox for the ACK (acknowledged) and UNACK (unacknowledged) options to display them in the table. Uncheck the checkbox to hide either of these event types so they do not appear in the table.
    Source
    Identifies the source device type of the event. Click the Source drop-down list and check the checkbox for the following source device types you want to filter from which the PW EMS receives events:
    • ACS
    • COM_VBBU
    • COM_VNODE
    • COM_VNODE_2G
    • COM_VNODE_4G
    • HNG

    Any checked device appears in the table. Uncheck the checkbox to hide source device event types so they do not appear in the table.
    Message (Default column) Displays the system message ID and type of error in detail.
  4. The system can store up to 1,000,000 events. The oldest events are deleted when the maximum amount of events allowed is reached. To set the maximum number of events, click the SETTINGS tab and enter the maximum number of events in the System field.
  5. Click the Auto Refresh slider On if you want to have the Events window refresh periodically once every 10 minutes.
  6. To sort table entries, position the cursor to the right of any column header until a gray arrow appears and click this arrow up (beginning of entry list) or down (end of entry list) to display results or vice versa, as shown below:
  7. Click More to select from the following event filter types that you want to use to filter or winnow the type of event information that you want to see in the ACTIVE EVENTS table. The event filter types shown in the following figure are described in the following table:

    Alarm Filter

    Description
    Device ID Enter the device ID from which to filter events.
    Object ID The module or internal path object from which to filter events.
    Message Enter message text from which to filter events.
    Description Enter a full or partial description from which to filter events.
    Timestamp Select a time (from and to) from the date calender and enter the time in hours, minutes and seconds (HH:MM:SS) and click Apply from which to filter events.
  8. Click LOGS at the top of the window to use as a short-cut to the Audit Logs page. This page can also be accessed from the navigation bar > Audit Logs.
Parent topic: Fault Management
